The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in theoretical physics. The most promising approach to their solution is to develop a mathematical theory that is able to capture the essence of quantum mechanics. In this paper, we develop such a theory. It is based on the idea that quantum mechanics is a special case of a more general theory of “quantum spaces.” A quantum space is a category that is equipped with a set of “observables” and a set of “measurements.” We show that the category of Hilbert spaces is a quantum space. We also show that there are many other quantum spaces. In particular, there is a quantum space that is isomorphic to the category of quantum states. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of great interest because of their extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The Myxozoa are thought to have evolved from a free-living cnidarian, but the evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive. We report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and show that the myxozoan and cnidarian genomes are strikingly similar, and that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique resource for understanding the origin and evolution of the Myxozoa. (Read more)

The ability of the immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key factor in the fight against infectious diseases. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We demonstrate that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is essential for the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import and to antagonize IFN signaling. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be relevant to other viruses that use the Nup98-Rae1 complex to evade the antiviral action of IFN. (Read more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This study shows that the variability of maize production will increase substantially under global warming, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. These results highlight the need for increased investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which will be critical to ensure food security in a warmer world.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and digestive physiology—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This work provides a blueprint for the use of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition and overlap in other systems. (Less)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is uncertain, and many businesses expect to remain open for a long time. Many businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans. Finally, we find evidence that grants are more effective than loans at increasing business resilience.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major concern in recent years. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean, which involve a combination of processes, such as nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean and will help to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. It also provides a baseline for future studies to assess the impact of the ongoing reduction of plastic debris in the ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is one of the most important adaptations that animals can make. In this study, we show that the ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother correlates with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in the number of litters produced but rather an increase in the number of offspring produced per litter. This increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability but rather an increase in the metabolic power of the mother. This suggests that the limiting factor on reproductive output in placental mammals is the metabolic power of the mother. This is an important finding because it suggests that the ability to increase the metabolic power of the mother is a key factor in the evolution of mammals. It also suggests that the metabolic power of the mother is a key factor in the evolution of the family. (Less)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA. The results also suggest that caspase-1 may be a potential target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for MSA. This study opens the door to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MSA and other synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources. This ability is achieved by the development of a communication network that is able to integrate information from scattered clusters of cells. This paper describes the nature of the communication network and the design principles that are used to achieve the desired properties. The design principles are important for understanding the structure and function of the endothelium and for developing new technologies that can control the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, including signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data and software are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We believe that this data source will be useful to many stakeholders, including policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and health researchers. We hope that the API will serve as a platform for future innovations in data collection and dissemination.

The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the ion channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel for the specific ion. The selectivity filter is also the most difficult part of the channel to study. In this work, we have demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally studied in a functional state.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. One of the most promising approaches is the use of natural products from the microbiome to develop new therapeutics. In this study, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These results support the use of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products for the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is a major factor in the heterochronous regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 is a major factor in the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in erythroid cells. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 is a potential target for therapeutic intervention in hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, and that this resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase SCD1. We also found that SREBP1 and SCD1 are central to the lipogenesis that protects cancer cells from ferroptosis. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapies for cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. We show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving the N terminus of STIM1. Our findings provide a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study may help to improve the safety of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. The NWFP was based on the premise that the decline of older forests was the primary driver of bird declines. However, our results show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests and that the primary driver of bird declines was the loss of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used acylide antibiotic, and that it is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is a step forward in the development of new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy can be applied to other classes of antibiotics and to other targets. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with large datasets, and also makes it difficult to apply the networks to problems with large images. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that can be trained with a small number of images. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and best-known groups of endemic species on Earth. The species flock is found in a single lake, occupying a large area of the African continent, and is thought to have evolved in response to the changing hydroclimate of the lake. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the Lake Malawi region, which shows that the species flock evolved in a much drier climate than today.
The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this use has a negative impact on sleep, with implications for performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) is a critical time in the Earth’s history, and one or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. The YDB is marked by a cooling of ∼3 °C, and the bolide impact hypothesis is supported by varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources, and the Os in the YDB spherules is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os in the YDB spherules is likely derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is still not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, and that its expression in the thymus and periphery is required for the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls, which are the primary food source for most beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetle diversity was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to their targets. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation antibodies for the treatment of COVID-19.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be more important for the maintenance of cultural variation than for its enhancement. This may be because larger populations are more likely to generate a greater diversity of individuals, which may be more likely to be adapted to the local environment.

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated allele. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, where it is produced by astrocytes. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain, which may be a consequence of the enhanced vulnerability of senescent synapses to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies also provide a potential mechanism for the protective effect of APOE2 alleles in AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,700 km in radius and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3, which is much higher than that of the outer core. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the liquid core, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. This study shows that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more favorable than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase under the conditions of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. This study provides a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. (Abridged)

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States, and its use is increasing among adolescents. The effects of marijuana on the brain are not well understood, and the consequences of chronic marijuana use are unknown. We show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also show increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the most complex and widespread form of human communication. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also predict the brain responses of human observers performing language tasks. This finding suggests that the most powerful artificial neural networks may be capturing the neural correlates of language comprehension. If so, this raises the possibility that artificial neural networks may one day allow us to understand the human brain mechanisms of language.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find good solutions or to its instability. We show that the instability of DL is due to the lack of theoretical understanding of the relationship between the stability of NNs and the existence of algorithms that can train them. We establish a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that can train stable NNs. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify that it is fast. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This work is a step toward understanding the relationship between stability and the existence of algorithms for training neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of the public to follow the rules. One of the most prominent arguments is that the public’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major factor in the spread of the virus. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed, and that the conclusion is not supported by the data. We discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human behavior and the interpretation of scientific evidence.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research for decades. In contrast, the uncultured human pathogen Mycobacterium lepromatosis has been studied for only a few years. Here, we present the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis and compare it with that of M. leprae. We find that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to cause peripheral neuropathy, and that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. These findings have implications for the study of leprosy and for the development of new therapeutics. (Less)

The evolution of entanglement is a fundamental question in quantum mechanics. It is also a challenging problem, as it is not amenable to a general solution. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, which is integrable. We also show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in terms of a generalized Gibbs ensemble, which is a generalization of the standard Gibbs ensemble to systems with many degrees of freedom. This result is a step toward a general understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. To combat the pandemic, a large-scale vaccination program is urgently needed. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature, and is highly attenuated in vivo. In addition, the vaccine candidate is codon optimized to improve its translation into large-scale production. These features, coupled with its potential use in mass vaccination programs, support its potential use in the fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, were also important transmission pathways during this period. This contradicts the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats, and it has important implications for the control of the disease.

The evolution of brain size is a topic of great interest to scientists and the public alike. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the ability to process information, is not as well understood. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is not driven by the evolution of brain size but by the evolution of the number of neurons. This is a major finding that has implications for the study of animal cognition and evolution in general.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the utility of TRAP1 inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function is limited by the inability to distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of many current TRAP1 inhibitors. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cytokinesis. ADF is also involved in the assembly and disassembly of the actin cytoskeleton, and is therefore a potential target for the treatment of diseases such as cancer and fibrosis. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin filament dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is enhanced by mechanical stress. This effect is critical for ADF to regulate actin filament dynamics in a physiological context. Our findings have implications for the design of new drugs that target ADF. They also provide a general mechanism for understanding the action of other proteins that regulate filament dynamics by mechanical means. (Read more)

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior. In addition, the findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also have implications for understanding the effects of fasting versus feeding on brain and behavior. The findings suggest that fasting may be a stronger suppressor of appetite than feeding. Finally, the results suggest that the brain may be a useful target for interventions aimed at reducing food intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the settlement was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of Madagascar is already detectable after a few centuries, suggesting that the island is a unique place for studying the effects of geography and demography on the human genome.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but has been controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that the influence of others’ positive experiences is particularly strong. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of social media in society. They also suggest that, contrary to popular belief, people do not need to observe others’ negative experiences to be affected by them. Instead, people may be affected by the positive and negative experiences of others, and that this may be a key mechanism for the influence of others on our emotions.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of mRNA modifications can alter the translation of these molecules, but the impact of these modifications on translation is not well understood. We show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNAs can modestly alter translation speed and the decoding of mRNA codons. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in the course of translation. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in regulating translation. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of healthy aging and for developing interventions to promote the feeling of worthwhile living.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology, but the extent to which the aquatic environment constrains the evolution of body size remains unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the aquatic environment constraining body size through energetic limitations. This work provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints on body size evolution and a better understanding of the evolution of body size in mammals.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a key factor in the development of the common cold, but the mechanism of temperature dependence is not known. We show that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is dependent on the innate immune response of infected cells, which is more efficient at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature.

The ability to sense and respond to environmental cues is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In bacteria, this process is often mediated by a chemosensory system that detects chemical signals and activates a cascade of events that ultimately leads to a change in the bacterial behavior. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This process is mediated by a chemosensory system that regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly growing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its effects on the environment. We show that the use of pesticides is not well monitored, and that the effects of pesticides on the environment are not well understood. We also show that the use of pesticides is having a negative impact on the environment, and that the effects of pesticides are not well understood.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus responsible for the disease has spread to many animal species. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is a common and important cervid in North America. We also show that the virus has the potential to spread between deer populations. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins in the brain. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is thought to be the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that soluble Aβ is toxic to neurons and that it is the primary cause of the neuroinflammatory response in AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This finding is supported by a survey of the chicken bone assemblage from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The results of this study provide evidence for the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, which was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a major factor in the regulation of gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs, RppH, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping of disulfide-stressed transcripts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The implications of these findings for the regulation of gene expression in response to disulfide stress are discussed. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although the immune response is essential for the resolution of infection, it can also contribute to the development of severe complications. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune response during sepsis. We demonstrate that arginine administration is more efficient than citrulline administration in restoring T cell function and proliferation and in decreasing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs. These results suggest that arginine could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study also provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental property of the planet, but it is still unknown at the level of detail of how the biomass of different taxa compares with one another. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, showing that plants are the most abundant kingdom, followed by animals, bacteria, and archaea. We also show that humans are the most abundant animals on Earth. Our results have implications for our understanding of the structure and dynamics of the biosphere and for the future of humanity.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves in such a way that the rate of change of its activity is approximately equal to the rate of change of its driving force. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity levels, and the critical behavior of such systems is believed to be universal. We report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a scaling limit of the well-known sandpile model. We discuss the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are limited. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned continuously. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond for applications in the quantum and photonics industries.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of biocides. However, the mode of action of these peptides against plant fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and mode of action of a plant cysteine-rich peptide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection and the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the proteome of the sperm changes substantially after they are transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become more abundant in the sperm after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and can cause severe bleeding in some cases. We show that the A1 domain in VWF can be switched between two states by force, and that this switching is important for VWF binding to platelets. The force-induced conformational changes explain the effects of mutations in VWD, and the force-induced switching provides a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWD, and may lead to new therapies for VWD. (Read more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, and we use it to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life, and for the design of sustainable societies. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from a variety of methods, including isotopic and paleontological evidence. However, the reliability of these methods has been questioned due to uncertainties regarding the accuracy of the isotopic and paleontological data, and the possibility of resetting of the isotopic record. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. The results presented here provide a new method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past and in the future.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important targets for drug development. Ion channels are classified into three major groups, K+, Na+, and Ca2+, and each group has its own unique channel family. The K+ channel family is the largest and most diverse, and it is further divided into three major groups, voltage-gated, ligand-gated, and calcium-activated. The calcium-activated K+ (BK) channel is the smallest and most specialized, and it is the only one that lacks a classic activation gate. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 627,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has remained largely enigmatic. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the erythrocyte, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of antimalarial strategies. (Less)

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and sensors. It is also a promising material for strain engineering, which is important for many applications. However, the strain-induced properties of diamond are not well understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the metallization can be reversed by strain engineering. This work provides a new way to control the properties of diamond, which can be used for strain engineering of diamond for applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease outcome in low humidity conditions. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. This may have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus disease in temperate regions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with the idea that the brain first builds phrases and then merges them into larger structures. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the brain’s processing of language.

The Wnt pathway is one of the most important signaling pathways in vertebrates, and it is essential for the development of the organism. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor and the scaffold Axin. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and that this differential regulation is important for the proper functioning of the pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. It is estimated that 30.5% of the population is obese, and this number is increasing. The causes of obesity are complex, but one of the most important factors is the ability to overeat. The brain region that is most strongly implicated in the regulation of eating is the lateral hypothalamus. We have identified a circuit in the lateral hypothalamus that is critical for the regulation of eating. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle is therefore a key component of sustainable agriculture. In this work, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal crop, barley, by a diazotrophic bacterium. This system is based on the use of a bacterial signal, rhizopine, which is produced by barley and can be used to control the expression of genes in the bacterium. This work represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to increase the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in cereal crops, and thus could have a significant impact on the sustainability of agriculture.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed alerts from the Global Forest Watch network with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. The program’s monitors were perceived to have influence over forest management, and the monitors’ patrols were perceived to be substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols. These findings have implications for the design of forest monitoring and governance systems in the Amazon and elsewhere.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36(±0.06) °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 5 million deaths worldwide. The lack of affordable vaccines for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) has been a major impediment to controlling the pandemic. Here we report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results provide a foundation for the development of a vaccine candidate that can be manufactured at large scale and at low cost, and that can be used to control the pandemic in LMICs. The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are activated by secreted ALKALs, which are also implicated in the development of neuroblastoma. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings have implications for the development of targeted therapies for neuroblastoma and other ALK-driven cancers.

The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has been responsible for devastating outbreaks throughout human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have provided key evolutionary insights into its emergence, but the number of genomes from this period are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, and our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. In this study, we show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated pools in a long-term field experiment. We also show that the effects of these practices on SOC storage are highly dependent on the type of crop rotation and the addition of manure. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses into humans and the development of strategies to mitigate that risk. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify the host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to spillover and spread of zoonotic viruses in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that this alkaloid is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator, Phelsuma geckos, and that this trait is convergent in two other species, Jaltomata herrerae and the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata spinosa. This work provides evidence that the color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the chemical biology of Campanulaceae. (Read more)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex and controversial topic. In particular, the period between the Roman Empire and the Middle Ages has been characterized by a lack of genetic data that could help to elucidate the processes that shaped the genetic structure of the continent. Here we present a study of the genetic history of a panel of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. (Less)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is the latest human coronavirus, causing ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the development of countermeasures against future coronavirus pandemics. This article is protected by copyright. All

We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and cost-effective approach for the identification of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. We demonstrate the ability to identify vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a diverse population of febrile patients. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The PCNA-pol δ holoenzyme is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human holoenzyme is more stable than its S. cerevisiae counterpart and that the holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the human lagging strand replication complex. It also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases caused by defects in lagging strand replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, but the ability to replicate RNA has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of a ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. The polymerase can also synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the polymerase can convert genetic information into functional molecules, a prerequisite for the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social well-being of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the treatment of tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of metal-binding metabolites is a well-established phenomenon, but the role of these metabolites in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes is not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is involved in copper homeostasis and that xanthocillin and other isocyanide products have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a foundation for further exploration of the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the impact of copper on fungal interactions with other microbes. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone is also significant because it is a product of diagenesis, not volcanism. The tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and amorphous silica in the sedimentary mudstone are cogenetic, indicating that the sediment was sourced from the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and magnetite are products of multiple aqueous solutions, possibly from multiple aqueous solutions, infiltrating the sediment source region and/or at the sediment–sediment bed/bedrock interface. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone is also significant because it is a product of high-temperature, high-pressure metamorphism, and the presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone is also significant because it is a product of diagenesis, not volcanism.

The impact of late-spring frosts (LSFs) on plants and animals is well known, but the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the resistance strategies of trees to LSFs are region-specific, and that the resistance strategies of trees are changing in response to the ongoing changes in LSFs. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not fully understood. We show that Th17 cells can contribute to colitis pathogenesis in two ways: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, and the cause of death is motor neuron degeneration. The disease is also highly variable in the time of onset, progression, and survival. The cause of the disease is unknown, and there are no treatments to slow the progression of the disease. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease and develop treatments. This method will enable the study of the disease in large numbers and will be a powerful tool for drug screening.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the gut microbiota and enhances the capacity of the vector to transmit the pathogen. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively transmit the pathogen to vertebrate hosts. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that includes the modern bird family Pygostylidae. However, the diversity of early branching members of this group is limited, obscuring our understanding of the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the avian tail. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to avoid being eaten by predators. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the ability to change color is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the ability of cancer cells to adapt to hypoxia is critical for their survival and growth. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the capacity of breast cancer cells to form tumor initiating cells, which are a feature of cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skin for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term “uterine vellum” is often used to describe this material, but the source of this material has been a subject of debate. Here, we present a method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We show that the source of this material was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, but rather the use of several species of animal, which could be locally available.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, and the timing of the event is uncertain. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, based on the age of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, and the interval of extinction is 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. The age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, and will provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily, which has been implicated in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in currently circulating viruses, and several studies have suggested that it is associated with higher virus infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structures of the D614 and G614 spike proteins and show that the G614 mutant spike adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein and may help to inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics.
