We consider repeated games with perfect information, where the payoffs depend only on the long-run behavior of the players. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even when the action sets are discrete. The result is also new when the payoff functions are Borel-measurable. The result is new even when the action sets are discrete.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical behavior of matter under pressure is a topic of great interest, but there is no general theory to explain the observed phenomena. In this work, we propose a new approach to the study of chemical properties under pressure, which is based on the calculation of two chemical potentials, chemical hardness and electronegativity. We show that these two properties decrease with pressure, and we use them to predict the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. We also show that the proposed chemical properties can be used to predict the chemical behavior of matter under pressure, and we use them to predict the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. This work provides a new perspective on the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. It also provides a new tool for the prediction of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure. This work is expected to be of interest to chemists, physicists, and materials scientists.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of changes in fire activity over the past century. However, we also find that climate change has been a major driver of fire activity in the past, and that climate change will continue to be a major driver in the future. We show that climate change has already caused warming of the global terrestrial biosphere, and that climate change will continue to cause warming in the future. We also show that climate change has the potential to reduce warming in the future, and that this effect is most pronounced under lower emission scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate change mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions in which the symbionts live, thereby enhancing their capacity to produce light. This glycan–bacteria–light relationship may be a common feature of the symbiosis between animals and their microbial partners. (Read more)

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. We believe that this approach will be useful in many domains. For example, it can be used to identify topics in social media data to understand public sentiment. It can also be used to identify topics in medical records to understand disease patterns. Finally, it can be used to identify topics in scientific publications to understand research trends. Our method is a step toward a more data-driven understanding of the world around us.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the introduction of plague into Europe was the consequence of repeated reintroductions, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the disease was introduced into Europe by multiple vectors, rather than by a single vector, and that the disease was maintained in Asia for centuries before its introduction into Europe. Our results suggest that the disease was maintained in Asia by a combination of human activities and climate fluctuations. (Less)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases to affect the California Current ecosystem. The disease has been linked to a densovirus, but the source of the virus is unknown. Here, we show that the densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. We also show that the virus has been present in the ecosystem for at least 72 y. This finding has important implications for the management of the disease, as it suggests that the virus has been present in the ecosystem for a long time and may be difficult to eradicate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The identification of targets for treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML and that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Read more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also revealed by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the study of the human history of the Indian Ocean. It will also be useful for the study of the human history of the African continent, as Madagascar is a unique window to the past of the island. (Less)

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the first line of defense in the fight against crop losses. However, their knowledge is often not used to its full potential, and their expertise is not fully exploited. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by crop experts across the country, can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our findings have implications for the design of agricultural monitoring systems, and for the training of agricultural experts in the use of remote sensing and crop models. They also have implications for the design of agricultural monitoring systems, and for the training of agricultural experts in the use of remote sensing and crop models. Finally, our findings have implications for the design of agricultural monitoring systems, and for the training of agricultural experts in the use of remote sensing and crop models.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, this view has been challenged by work showing that short-term synaptic facilitation can also support memory. Here we propose a model that shows how synaptic facilitation can be a substrate of memory. We show that the dynamics of synaptic facilitation can be used to encode information in the form of dynamic variables that control the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time within the language domain. This is important because it is the binding of linguistic features that is thought to be the key to the emergence of language.

The response of soil respiration to warming is a key indicator of the impact of climate change on the global carbon cycle. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to warming across the full range of climatic conditions. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and show that the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across biomes. We also show that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with increasing temperature, suggesting that the response of soil respiration to warming will depend on the climatic conditions of the region. This work provides a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for the study of the evolution of life on Earth. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional climate models in the assessment of the impact of climate change on drought risk. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. It was the first time that a new state of matter had been discovered, and it was the first time that a new class of materials had been discovered. The discovery of the trinitite quasicrystal in 2016, 71 years after the Trinity test, is a major event in the history of science and technology. It is the first time that a new quasicrystal has been discovered in the aftermath of a nuclear test.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase” reaction, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the diiron enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the diiron enzyme. AcsF is the cyclase in R. gelatinosus, whereas alphaproteobacterial cyclases require a newly discovered protein, BciE, encoded by a gene conserved in these organisms. These data delineate three classes of the diiron cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we identified ASK1 as a key regulator of neuroinflammation in EAE. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages reduced the severity of EAE, suggesting that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings provide insights into the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. This finding has important implications for the future of California, as the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions is expected to increase in the future.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing a more effective approach to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of forgetting in behavior.

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in the news in a large, cross-national sample. It finds that, on average, people around the world are more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. This work also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycINFO Database Record

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in ORAI1 and STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, which result in hematological abnormalities and myopathy, respectively. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These findings provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the propagation of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats to other animals and humans are not fully understood. Here, we identified and characterized a highly concentrated immunosuppressant protein (MTX) in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX, but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of influenza virus in humans. (PsycINFO Database

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic enzyme that converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular target engagers. Finally, we show that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. It also provides a metabolic target for the design of drugs that can selectively inhibit lymphoma growth. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many fields, including condensed-matter physics, photonics, and quantum information science. The results are also expected to be of interest to researchers in the semiconductor industry, as the fabrication process is compatible with silicon-based technologies. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants are known from the Cretaceous period, and the origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia vidalii, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. The study of this plant, based upon the study of more than 1,000 specimens, provides a detailed analysis of the morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction. The results suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, and that Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. The results also suggest that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. This research provides a better understanding of the origin of the flowering plants. (Less)

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes, which are the oldest viral sequences available. We show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The study also shows that the evolution of B19V is faster than previously thought. This is important for understanding the evolution of DNA viruses in general. (Less)

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and well-known indicators of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest time series available. The results are consistent with the IPCC AR5 model projections, but the uncertainty is larger. The results also show that the acceleration of sea level rise is not uniform in space and time. The acceleration is strongest in the Pacific Ocean, and it is strongest in the western Pacific Ocean.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the causes of the increase in pain are not well understood. We show that pain is increasing in the United States, with each successive birth cohort reporting more pain than the previous cohort. The increase is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and it is likely to continue.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is critical to understanding the mechanisms of catalysis. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results of this study provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, highlighting the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the active site is critical to understanding the mechanism of the reaction and the role of the cofactor in catalysis. The results of this study also highlight the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into the dynamics of enzyme active sites. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown promising results in vitro and in vivo, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment was highly effective in preventing disease, and in reducing the severity of disease in the event of infection. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of nonhuman primate models for the study of emerging respiratory viruses. (Read more)

Suspension rates in US schools have increased by 600% since 2000. This study shows that suspension rates can be reduced by encouraging teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention was scalable and effective, and it bolstered the respect students had for their teachers. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on transcription. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles. Intriguingly, the stalling profiles are controlled by the pol II fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. Increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings could make a significant contribution to reducing these problems. However, the impact of increasing the proportion of plant-based meals on sales has not been studied. We show that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting increased sales by 14.5 percentage points, equivalent to a proportional increase of 79%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our results also suggest that increasing the proportion of plant-based meals available in catering settings is a promising approach for achieving the goals of the Sustainable Development Goals. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell, and is the target for many drugs. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of breast cancer cell lines expressing oncogenes, and how this is correlated with the oncogene’s dependence on the MAPK pathway. We also use a recently developed technique to sequence intact glycans, and show how oncogene expression dramatically alters the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a resource for the breast cancer community to identify surface proteins that may be useful as biomarkers and drug targets. (Read more)

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal cost and that may have a modest positive effect on turnout. Our results also suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail are likely to be more pronounced in the long run than in the short run.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the molecular basis of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and the presence of this interface may contribute to the unique immune evasion and evasion of interferon responses observed for SARS-CoV-2. These results provide a molecular understanding of the unique features of SARS-CoV-2, which may be useful in the development of therapeutics and vaccines. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the world, and it is also a risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic increase of the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 contributes to the edema via AQP4. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia. It also provides a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding and addressing the challenge of selective inference in a variety of settings.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key transcription factor for the development of vascular ECs. ETV2 is able to induce the expression of endothelial development factors in both primary human fibroblasts and human induced pluripotent stem cells. Furthermore, ETV2 is able to induce the formation of vascular networks in vivo. These findings provide a better understanding of the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new method for the generation of vascular ECs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened a new field of research in the field of RTKs. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the two ligands encoded by the zebrafish genome are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new perspective on the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also opens the door to the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by oncogenic RTKs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO β-cells. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which is a feature that provides evolutionary advantages but also complicates the packaging of the genome into virions. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves a network of interactions that is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation of this mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that govern the packaging of the influenza A virus genome. They also provide a starting point for the development of new strategies to control influenza epidemics. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions, which are the primary cause of cardiovascular diseases. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a quantitative assessment of the role of human activities in increasing wildfire activity. We show that human activities have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occurred in areas with higher fuel moisture. Actions to reduce the role of human activities in increasing wildfire activity should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. (Abridged)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social well-being of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time to detectable plasma viral load is very sensitive to the rate of viral production, and that the rate of viral production is faster than previously thought. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by 2 d, whereas favipiravir given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the development of more effective antiviral treatments for ZIKV. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The causes of bleaching are poorly understood, and the consequences of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still largely unknown. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, which in turn leads to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in light of the ongoing breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. Here, we show that intestinal tumors lead to the activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, which in turn triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can repress the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduce activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impair the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a weakening of the Southern Hemisphere monsoons and a drying of the continent. However, the timing of this change is controversial, and the mechanisms are not well understood. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a unique volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong solar forcing. This suggests that the volcanic eruptions may have contributed to the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This is an important finding, as it provides a mechanism for the start of deglaciation that is independent of the westerlies. It also provides a potential explanation for the timing of deglaciation in other parts of the world. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult nervous system and for developing new strategies for promoting regeneration in the CNS.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key parameter in the study of evolution. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that of a mouse mutant in which the rate of recombination is reduced. The results suggest that the rate of recombination in plants is similar to that in yeast, and that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of a small fraction of neurons is sufficient to generate the observed static signal. This activity is not random, but is organized in topographies that are reproducible across subjects. We have developed a method to identify these topographies, which we call resting state networks. We have shown that these networks are present in healthy subjects and are altered in Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and schizophrenia. The method is applicable to other dynamic systems, such as the heart, and may be useful in the study of other complex systems.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is found on all mRNAs that are translated in vivo. In bacteria, the 5′ NAD+ cap is also essential for translation, but in bacteria it is not found on all mRNAs that are translated. In this study, we show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is also found on mRNAs in eukaryotes. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNAs, but not on mature mRNAs. These results suggest that the 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation in eukaryotes. This is the first report of a 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the DCCT, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a possible epigenetic mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. This mechanism may be relevant for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes complications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that gut permeability is increased in alcohol-dependent subjects and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it could be a target in the management of this disease.

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds, and the fruit is a major source of food flavor. However, the biosynthetic pathways of many of the volatile compounds in tomato fruit are not known. We have identified a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for the study of the biosynthesis of other classes of volatile compounds in plants. (Read more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe when species diversity is low. This is because the diversity-functioning relationship becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes: (i) the greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions, and (ii) an increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of global warming and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of natural systems and the services they provide.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is also the site of the grid cell, a fundamental component of the brain’s internal representation of space. However, the anatomical organization of the grid cell network is still debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they show strong coupling among themselves. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the grid cell network and may help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the formation of the internal representation of space. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This is an example of how a parasite may have evolved a means of synchronizing its reproduction with that of its host.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The dopamine system is also implicated in mood and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantivity are organized into specialized integrative units, the striosome–dendron bouquets, that are likely to be critical to the function of the system.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This may be a fundamental mechanism of social connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust their heart rate to meet the changing demands of the body. This is achieved by integrating information from the heart’s electrical activity with information from the Ca2+ stores in the heart’s muscle cells. This study reveals that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of this process.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote rice defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, which are the main immune cells in the body.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a sustained increase in neural activity. However, this view has been challenged by work showing that short-term synaptic facilitation can also support memory. Here we propose a model that shows that memory can be supported by intrinsic plasticity in the nervous system. We show that the activity of a single neuron can be used to write information into a dynamic memory register that can be read back out for processing. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language. It also provides a mechanism for the binding of linguistic features over time, which is a key process in language processing.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biotechnology community.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides many ecosystem services to society. However, it is also a highly vulnerable area to the impacts of nutrient loading. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of coastal nutrients. This finding is important because it suggests that coastal eutrophication may be driven by a large number of small tributaries rather than a few large ones. Our findings have implications for coastal management and restoration, as well as for the design of nutrient reduction strategies.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare combinations of positions. We show that this bias can be understood in terms of the underlying network topology, and we discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of mathematical modeling and a mouse model to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, which can lead to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. These changes can predispose the brain to paroxysmal abnormalities. This work offers mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. These findings may help to guide the development of new therapies for patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid change in climate, and the consequences of such a change are unknown. To understand the consequences of such a change, it is important to understand how the Earth system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the consequences of rapid climate change. (Abridged)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a promising tool for reducing deforestation, but more research is needed to understand the conditions under which it can be most effective. (Less)

The exocyst complex is a large protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent it was inherited from. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the alleles it inherited. In this study, we show that the multiple alleles of sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can produce a new set of modular sexual phenotypes. These results suggest that the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles can have a profound effect on the sexual phenotype of a species.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photodecomposable adducts of vitamin A. The retina is also challenged by the presence of iron, which is a cofactor for many redox active enzymes. We show that iron levels impact the retina and that the presence of iron can promote the photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Siphonophores are a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization, as they have a wide range of prey types, and are able to evolve new prey-capture structures. We show that siphonophore tentacles have strong evolutionary associations with prey type, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. Our findings help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological evolution, and contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. This work also highlights the importance of studying the evolutionary history of predators, as it can help us understand the origin and evolution of morphological innovations.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology, and the fossil record is sparse between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene that shows a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, which is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like hand morphology. (Less)

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic enzyme that converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT1/2 knockout blocks HCT-116 colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that they are effective cellular target engagers. Finally, we show that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule SHMT inhibitors as a cancer therapy. It also provides a metabolic target for the design of drugs that can selectively inhibit lymphoma growth. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets. This study is a step toward understanding the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and should be followed by more research in this area.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased global food production by 100% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction is a result of the same factors that guided the design of sauropods, which were the largest animals that walked Earth.
